words.def: Applied carving - background which is worked separately and then applied, rather than being worked in place.
words.name: Applied carving

words.def: Architrave - ornamental mouldings around a door or window frame, covering the joint between the frame and plaster.
words.name: Architrave

words.def: Bead - a semicircular piece of moulding.
words.name: Bead

words.def: Bench dog or Bench stop - a peg standing proud of the bench surface.
words.name: Bench dog

words.def: Blind - joinery with mating surfaces not protruding through the face or end grain of the pieces being joined. Example - blind mortise and tenon joint
words.name: Blind

words.def: Billet - 1. a short piece of log particularly used for fuel; 2. a split out piece of a bolt of wood.
words.name: Billet

words.def: Bolster (pillow, cross head) - 1. shoulder; 2. a timber between a post and a beam to increase the bearing or shorten the span.
words.name: Bolster

words.def: Bolt - a piece of log cut to specific length, usually a short length from which products such as shingles are split or cut. Sometimes also called a billet or round.
words.name: Bolt

words.def: Brace - a hand tool used to drill holes, having a knobbed handle on the top to which pressure is applied, and a U-shaped grip in the middle which is used to rotate the drill bit.
words.name: Brace

words.def: Burl - a knotty growth from a tree with a convoluted, complex grain.
words.name: Burl

words.def: Cannel, channel - the concavity of a gouge blade.
words.name: Cannel, channel

words.def: Card scraper - a flat blade with a burred edge used for smoothing.
words.name: Card scraper

words.def: Caul - A strip or block of wood used to distribute or direct clamping force
words.name: Caul

words.def: Chatoyance - the effect seen in dramatic wood grain direction changes as seen in flame figured maple.
words.name: Chatoyance

words.def: Chip carving - incised surface decoration, usually geometric.
words.name: Chip carving

words.def: Chops - a type of vise.
words.name: Chops

words.def: Climb cut - On a table saw or router, cutting against the normal feed direction at the end of the cut to prevent tearout.
words.name: Climb cut

words.def: Close grain - woods with very fine fibers of cells (wood grain) that are not visibly porous.
words.name: Close grain

words.def: Conversion - reduction of a whole log into pieces suitable for working. Conversion can be done in three basic ways, sawn, hewn, or split.
words.name: Conversion

words.def: Crook - longitudinal bending to one side, caused by uneven seasoning or grain. (See Wood warping)
words.name: Crook

words.def: Crotch - the section of a tree where a branch divides from the trunk, or the trunk divides in two; typically an area of convoluted grain.
words.name: Crotch

words.def: Crossgrain - working perpendicular to the grain.
words.name: Crossgrain

words.def: Crosscut - a cut made perpendicular to the grain.
words.name: Crosscut

words.def: Crown of thorns - a system of self-supporting and interlocking pieces.
words.name: Crown of thorns

words.def: Cruck - a pair of crooked, structural timbers in a timber frame building. Crucks act as both posts and rafters like an A-frame.
words.name: Cruck

words.def: Cup - transverse bending, convex or concave, usually predictable, considering grain orientation. (see Wood warping)
words.name: Cup

words.def: Dado - a slot made across the grain. Typically, the slot is made by milling, chiseled, or sawed.
words.name: Dado

words.def: Dovetail joint - a joint technique most commonly used in woodworking joinery. Noted for its resistance to being pulled apart (tensile strength), the dovetail joint is commonly used to join the sides of a drawer to the front.
words.name: Dovetail joint

words.def: Drill - (verb) the process of making holes in a material or (noun) a tool for drilling holes.
words.name: Drill

words.def: Face - when a board has one side that is wider than the other, the wider side is referred to as the face (as opposed to the edge). May also refer to the face that is to be visible in the finished item.
words.name: Face

words.def: Fence - a flat and straight length of some material, usually wood, steel or aluminium, which provides a reference for tools to work against, or which prevents the work from sliding.
words.name: Fence

words.def: Fiber/fibre - the fine tube-like structure of wood which is hollow and determines the grain direction.
words.name: Fiber/fibre

words.def: Figure - naturally occurring decorative patterns in wood, caused by either growth increments or tissue orientation.
words.name: Figure

words.def: Firmer - a strong chisel for general work or mortising, may have square sides or bevels on both sides.
words.name: Firmer

words.def: Fishtail chisel or gouge - a chisel or gouge with a splayed end.
words.name: Fishtail chisel

words.def: Flat gouge - a gouge with minimal curvature, used for finishing and smoothing.
words.name: Flat gouge

words.def: Flitch - a board in which the round of the trunk is still visible, a rough-cut board.
words.name: Flitch

words.def: Flute - a deep channel cut in wood* occasionally denotes the cannel of a gouge.
words.name: Flute

words.def: Foxing - a yellow-brown discoloration of wood due to fungal infection.
words.name: Foxing

words.def: French cleat - a molding used to hang cabinets
words.name: French cleat

words.def: Fret saw - a saw with a very fine toothed blade used for delicate cuts in thin material.
words.name: Fret saw

words.def: Frosting - regular indented patterns created with a special-purpose punch called a froster.
words.name: Frosting

words.def: Grain - the longitudinal fibers in wood.
words.name: Grain

words.def: Gouge - a chisel-like tool with a curved cutting edge.
words.name: Gouge

words.def: Green wood - unseasoned wood; freshly harvested timber, usually with a high moisture content.
words.name: Green wood

words.def: Grit - the grade of particles in sandpaper or sharpening stones which determines the aggressiveness of the cut.
words.name: Grit

words.def: Groove - a slot or channel made with the grain, usually on the end-grain in preparation for a tongue and groove joint.
words.name: Groove

words.def: Grooving- a rectangular sinking in the surface of any material.
words.name: Grooving

words.def: Hand plane - see Plane.
words.name: Hand plane

words.def: Hardwood - wood from an angiosperm tree, i.e. a tree in the division Magnoliophyta. Despite the name, not necessarily very hard or dense wood (e.g. balsa is a hardwood), although generally harder than softwoods.
words.name: Hardwood

words.def: Heart shake - a shake (i.e. crack or split) radiating out from the heartwood.
words.name: Heart shake

words.def: Heel - the corner of a chisel, knife, or gouge bevel which meets the back of the blade and polishes the cut.
words.name: Heel

words.def: Hold down or hold fast - a hold-down iron, fitting into a hole in a bench, tightened or loosened by hammer taps.
words.name: Hold down or hold fast

words.def: Hollow grinding - a concave bevel on a chisel, gouge, or knife.
words.name: Hollow grinding

words.def: Incannel - the concave surface of a gouge; a gouge sharpened on the concave surface.
words.name: Incannel

words.def: Interlocked grain - wood grain which has multiple longitudinal directions in alternating layers, typical of many tropical hardwoods, and very difficult to work and to produce smooth surfaces.
words.name: Interlocked grain

words.def: Jig saw - a tool that can form circular cuts by moving the work piece past a blade rapidly moving up and down.
words.name: Jig saw

words.def: Joiner - a woodworker who does finer work than a framing carpenter.
words.name: Joiner

words.def: Jointer - 1. a power plane used to straighten boards and square edges, sometimes called a joiner; 2. an intermediate length hand plane, a jointer plane.
words.name: Jointer

words.def: Kerf - the gap left when material is removed by a saw. The width of the kerf is equal to the set of the saw.
words.name: Kerf

words.def: Knot - A circular pattern in timber, caused by a dead branch that was not fully integrated into the tree before it was cut down. A loose knot is one that cannot be relied upon to remain in place in the piece. A tight knot, on the other hand, is fixed by growth or position in the wood structure so that it firmly retains its place in the surrounding wood.
words.name: Knot

words.def: Lead - the tendency for wood that is being cut to direct the saw parallel to its grain.
words.name: Lead

words.def: LathArt - a type of folk art that uses lath from old plaster and lath walls
words.name: LathArt

words.def: Molding - a strip of material with various profiles used to cover transitions between surfaces or for decoration.
words.name: Molding

words.def: Mortise or Mortice - a cavity or hole (generally rectangular) in a piece of wood, meant to receive a tenon or a hinge
words.name: Mortise

words.def: Mitre (UK, Cda) or Miter (US) - a joint made by fastening together pieces with the ends cut at an angle.
words.name: Mitre

words.def: Mitre box (UK, Cda) or Miter box (US) - a box used for making mitre joints by having slots to guide a saw at the desired angle for the joint.
words.name: Mitre box

words.def: Off fall - Scrap created by making a cut. Abbreviated as fall.
words.name: Off fall

words.def: Outcannel - the convex surface of a gouge; a gouge sharpened on the convex surface.
words.name: Outcannel

words.def: Plane (tool) - (verb) the process of removing material in thin shavings in order to make it flat, or (noun) a tool for planing.
words.name: Plane (tool)

words.def: Plane iron - cutting part of a hand plane.
words.name: Plane iron

words.def: Planer - or thicknesser. a machine which reduces the thickness of boards.
words.name: Planer

words.def: Quarter-sawn - a plank with growth rings perpendicular to the wider face. (See Wood grain)
words.name: Quarter-sawn

words.def: Rabbet - A 'groove' cut parallel to, and at the edge of, a board.
words.name: Rabbet

words.def: Rail - Horizontal member of a frame on a door, window or panel.
words.name: Rail

words.def: Rasp - a long and flat steel tool with raised teeth for shaping wood.
words.name: Rasp

words.def: Reed - a series of beads in a row.
words.name: Reed

words.def: Relief cut - short straight cuts made at right angles to a curved layout so sharper than normal curves can be cut with a jig saw or band saw.
words.name: Relief cut

words.def: Riffler - a paddle-shaped rasp.
words.name: Riffler

words.def: Rift sawn - rip sawing of lumber (timber) perpendicular to the grain, often confused with quarter sawn.
words.name: Rift sawn

words.def: Ring shake - a natural type of split (shake) occurring between the annual rings.
words.name: Ring shake

words.def: Rip - a cut made parallel to the grain.
words.name: Rip

words.def: Route - to cut a channel or groove. See router (woodworking).
words.name: Route

words.def: S2S - lumber, usually furniture grade hardwood, with two sides planed. (S4S - four sides)
words.name: S2S

words.def: Saw rasp - a rasp with saw teeth.
words.name: Saw rasp

words.def: Scorp - a drawknife with a curved, sometimes completely circular blade, often used for hollowing out objects such as bowls.
words.name: Scorp

words.def: Scratch awl - a sharp-pointed hand tool used to mark wood for cutting, usually used in joinery or when a more precise mark is need beyond that provided by a pencil or other method of marking out the cut.
words.name: Scratch awl

words.def: Scribe - the woodworking technique of shaping the end of a moulding or frame component to neatly fit the contours of an abutting member.
words.name: Scribe

words.def: Scroll saw - a motorized fretsaw.
words.name: Scroll saw

words.def: Seasoning - reducing the moisture content of wood before working to prevent cracking, splitting, and other damage due to drying.
words.name: Seasoning

words.def: Shake - 1. a crack or split in wood, caused by damage or drying; 2. a split (as opposed to sawn) shingle.
words.name: Shake

words.def: Shoot - planing an edge straight or square. See Shooting board.
words.name: Shoot

words.def: Slab - 1. a partially round cut from a log; 2. In Australian English a slab is a plank.
words.name: Slab

words.def: Slab-cut - a plank with growth rings roughly parallel to the wider face.
words.name: Slab-cut

words.def: Slick - a giant chisel used in framing and traditional building construction.
words.name: Slick

words.def: Slip - a shaped stone used for sharpening non-flat blades such as gouges.
words.name: Slip

words.def: Snib - a wooden toggle used to hold the work on a table.
words.name: Snib

words.def: Softwood - wood from a gymnosperm tree, i.e. trees in the divisions Pinophyta and Ginkgophyta Despite the name, not necessarily very soft or light wood (e.g. douglas-fir is a softwood).
words.name: Softwood

words.def: Spalting - a change in the texture, strength and color of wood caused by colonies of fungus growing within the dead wood. Where colonies of fungus meet, fine black lines - often considered a desirable feature, can be seen.
words.name: Spalting

words.def: Split - to longitudinally separate wood along grain layers.
words.name: Split

words.def: Spokeshave - a tool used to shape and smooth wooden rods and shafts - often for use as wheel spokes and chair legs.
words.name: Spokeshave

words.def: Square - 1. a tool such as a steel square, try square, combination square; 2. a right angle; 3. an area of 100 sq. ft.
words.name: Square

words.def: Stickers - a small block of wood used to separate boards that are in the process of drying.
words.name: Stickers

words.def: Sticking - a moulding that is part of a larger piece of wood such as a frame (as opposed to being applied).
words.name: Sticking

words.def: Stile (or sometimes style) - vertical member of a frame on a door, window or panel.
words.name: Stile

words.def: Stringer - in stairs, a is a timber (usually 2"x12") that supports the treads and rises in a staircase.
words.name: Stringer

words.def: Sweep - 1. the curvature of a gouge, ranging from flat (little curvature, but not actually flat else it would be a chisel) to deep or quick; a warping defect in a piece of wood.
words.name: Sweep

words.def: Tear out - broken or torn fibres resulting from damage as the blade of a tool exits the cut.
words.name: Tear out

words.def: Tenon - is a projection on the end of a piece of wood for insertion into a mortise.
words.name: Tenon

words.def: Tread - in stairs the part that is stepped on.
words.name: Tread

words.def: True - something which is accurately placed, shaped, or sized. To true up two pieces of wood is to make them align. The correct size or shape.
words.name: True

words.def: Twist - longitudinal twisting of wood due to uneven seasoning or grain. (See Wood warping)
words.name: Twist

words.def: Undercutting - cutting away from an edge to increase the sense of relief or thinness.
words.name: Undercutting

words.def: Veiner - a small deep gouge.
words.name: Veiner

words.def: Veneer (wood) - very thin slices of wood used for inlay or to cover surfaces.
words.name: Veneer (wood)

words.def: Veneer saw - specialty tool for trimming veneer.
words.name: Veneer saw

words.def: Wane - an edge of a sawn board where the bark or surface of the trunk remains.
words.name: Wane

words.def: Warp - distorted lumber, such as a twist, cup or a bow. (See Wood warping)
words.name: Warp

words.def: Wasting - quickly removing wood during carving, usually with an adze, knife, or rasp.
words.name: Wasting

words.def: Waste - wood that will be removed in the finished work, often retained during working as a handle.
words.name: Waste

words.def: Wood - an organic material, a natural composite of cellulose fibers (which are strong in tension) embedded in a matrix of lignin which resists compression.
words.name: Wood
